Gyges, the aforementioned King of Lydia, discovers one of these objects. In Norse mythology, these objects include a treasure found by Sigurd, Andvarinaut (ond-VAR-ee-nowt), and a gift forged for Odin, Draupnir (DROWP-neer).
During the war against the Titans, a "Helm of Invisibility" was created for this Greek god of the underworld.

bonuses.leadin: Bernardino de Sahagun translated Christian psalms and gospels into the language of these people, adding elements such as Mary being impregnated by a quetzal feather. For 10 points each:
answers: Aztecs [accept answers such as Mexica or people from Aztlan; prompt on indigenous people or Indians or Mexicans]
Florentine Codex [or General History of the Things of New Spain; or Historia General de las Cosas de Nueva España]
parts: Name these people whom Sahagun attempted to get to stop worshiping indigenous gods such as Quetzalcoatl.
Sahagun disparagingly equated this Aztec god of darkness with the pagan Jupiter. In many depictions, one of this god's feet is replaced with an obsidian mirror.
Sahagun included many of his observations on indigenous religion in this twelve-book compendium on Aztec culture, which is commonly named for a city in Italy.

bonuses.leadin: In this people's myth system, the world was originally made of water, until a god descended on a golden chain with a snail shell full of sand. For 10 points each:
answers: lightning [or thunder; or thunderbolts; or thunderstorms; prompt on the sky or heaven; prompt on the weather]
parts: Name this ethnic group. In this people's creation myth, the world is created from dirt spread by a five-toed chicken.
The creator of humanity in Yoruba religion, Obatala, was one of these spirits. These servants of Olodumare are also venerated in many religions of the West African diaspora.
The popular orisha Shango was a god of this domain. Zeus and Thor were also gods of this natural phenomenon.

bonuses.leadin: John Tzetzes (ZEET-zees) reports that, upon hearing he would die in Nemea, this man fled to Locris and died in its temple to Nemean Zeus. For 10 points each:
answers: The Catalogue of Women [or Gynaikôn Katálogos; or Ehoiai; do not accept "Megalai Ehoiai" or "the Great Ehoiai"]
parts: Name this author. In a poem, this man lectures Perses, "the destroyer," and recounts the Five Ages of Man.
Hesiod's Works and Days distinguishes between two forms of this deity, who caused a feud between several Olympian goddesses by throwing the Golden Apple of Discord into their midst.
The Greek name for this fragmentary, five-book Hesiod poem comes from its use of the phrase "or like" to transition between different episodes, which tell of various heroines and their families.
answers_sanitized: Hesiod [or Hesiodos] (the poem is Works and Days)
The Catalogue of Women [or Gynaikon Katalogos; or Ehoiai; do not accept "Megalai Ehoiai" or "the Great Ehoiai"]

parts: Identify this role also occupied by Nandi, a white bull and companion of Shiva.
The rat Mooshika is the mount for this Hindu god, Shiva’s elephant-headed son.
The goddess Lakshmi's mount is one of these creatures. Demeter turned Ascalaphus into one of these creatures for revealing that Persephone had eaten pomegranate seeds.

parts: Identify this father of Aschius and Senius who was killed during an argument with his brother, Romulus.
Romulus and Remus came from this Italian city, which was itself founded by Aeneas' son, Ascanius.
The settlement of Pallantium was founded by this Greek king from Arcadia, whose son Pallas fights alongside the Trojans in the Aeneid.

bonuses.leadin: It's not lethargy, but consuming the products of the lotus trees on the island of the Lotus Eaters causes this affliction. For 10 points each:
answers: they forgot about their life on earth [or amnesia; or equivalents that describe loss of memory; or oblivion; prompt on answers like sleepiness or torpor]
parts: Name this affliction that also befell people who drank from the River Lethe.

This son of Armenius does not drink from the River Lethe ("LEE-the"), and thus recollects his experiences in the Underworld when he comes back to life on his funeral pyre. This character is the subject of a "myth" told at the end of Plato's Republic.
The Olympians swear their strongest oaths by this more prominent river of the Greek underworld, which separates the worlds of the living and the dead.

bonuses.leadin: Polynices (poll-ee-NICE-eez) bribed Eriphyle (uh-RIFF-uh-lee) with this object so that Eriphyle's husband would join his alliance. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this object, depicting a two-headed serpent, which has the power to grant perpetual youth and beauty.
Polynices offered Eriphyle the necklace so that her husband would join this alliance. This group of warriors led an Argive army against a chronically-troubled city ruled by Eteocles.
Harmonia received the necklace as a gift for her wedding to this Phoenician prince, who founded Thebes and brought the alphabet to Greece.
answers_sanitized: golden necklace of Harmonia [prompt on necklace]
Seven Against Thebes [or Hepta Epi Thebas]
